--- title: "Tutorial 3: Building and Working with DataFrames" date: now author: "Danet and Becks, based on originals by Delmas and Griffiths" format: html: embed-resources: true title-block-banner: true --- Working with vectors, arrays and matrices is important. But quite often, we want to collect high-dimension data (multiple variables) from our simulations and store them in a spreadsheet type format. As you've seen in Tutorial 1, there are plotting macros (`@df`) within the `StatsPlots` package that allow us to work with data frame objects from the `DataFrames` package. A second benefit of the data frame object is that we can export it as a `csv` file and import this into **R** where we may prefer working on plotting and statistics. To this end, here we will also introduce the `CSV` package, which is very handy for exporting DataFrame objects to csv files, and importing them as well, if you'd like. ## The Data Frame To initialise a dataframe you use the `DataFrame` function from the **DataFrames** package: ::: {#e3a9c962 .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.julia .cell-code} dat = DataFrame(col1=[], col2=[], col3=[]) # we use [] to specify an empty column of any type and size. ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ```{=html}
0×3 DataFrame
Rowcol1col2col3
AnyAnyAny
``` ::: ::: Alternately, you can specify the data type for each column. ::: {#3add739c .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.julia .cell-code} dat1 = DataFrame(col1=Float64[], col2=Int64[], col3=Float64[]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ```{=html}
0×3 DataFrame
Rowcol1col2col3
Float64Int64Float64
``` ::: ::: Of course, `col1` is not the only label you provide: variable names are super important and the conventions we use in **R** are also important here in **Julia**, e.g. `a_b` or `AaBa` but not `a b` (no spaces allowed) or `a.b` (because the (dot) `.` functions as an operator). ::: {#d82f8802 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.julia .cell-code} # provide informative column titles using: dat2 = DataFrame(species=[], size=[], rate=[]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ```{=html}
0×3 DataFrame
Rowspeciessizerate
AnyAnyAny
``` ::: ::: ### Allocating or adding data to a data frame. To add data to a dataframe, we use the `push!` (read as push bang) command. ::: {#56d354e3 .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.julia .cell-code} species = "D.magna" size = 2.2 rate = 4.2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ``` 4.2 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#ba9f8562 .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.julia .cell-code} # push!() arguments: data frame, data push!(dat2, [species, size, rate]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ```{=html}
1×3 DataFrame
Rowspeciessizerate
AnyAnyAny
1D.magna2.24.2
``` ::: ::: Of course, the `push!()` function can append data to the existing data frame. It is worth noting that `push!` can only append one row at a time. But since Julia is so good with loops (compared to R), this will make adding data to a dataframe really easy, and we'll learn how to do this in the next tutorial. What makes the `!` (bang) function very useful is that you can append (or remove, with `pop!()`) items to an object without having to assign it. ::: {#eb201795 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.julia .cell-code} species2 = "D.pulex" size2 = 1.8 rate2 = 3.1 # push!() arguments: data frame, data push!(dat2, [species2, size2, rate2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ```{=html}
2×3 DataFrame
Rowspeciessizerate
AnyAnyAny
1D.magna2.24.2
2D.pulex1.83.1
``` ::: ::: ### Helper Functions for Data Frames You can print data frames using `println` ::: {#73fc4cc2 .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.julia .cell-code} println(dat2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 2×3 DataFrame Row │ species size rate │ Any Any Any ─────┼───────────────────── 1 │ D.magna 2.2 4.2 2 │ D.pulex 1.8 3.1 ``` ::: ::: There are `first` and `last` function that are like `head` and `tail` in R and elsewhere, with a first argument the data frame and the second argument the number of rows. ::: {#1b02ddab .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.julia .cell-code} first(dat2, 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ```{=html}
2×3 DataFrame
Rowspeciessizerate
AnyAnyAny
1D.magna2.24.2
2D.pulex1.83.1
``` ::: ::: ::: {#d4547ae1 .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.julia .cell-code} last(dat2,2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ```{=html}
2×3 DataFrame
Rowspeciessizerate
AnyAnyAny
1D.magna2.24.2
2D.pulex1.83.1
``` ::: ::: And as we learned with matrices and arrays, the `[row, column]` method also works for data frames: ::: {#c2077023 .cell execution_count=11} ``` {.julia .cell-code} dat2[1,2] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ``` 2.2 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#85ff658b .cell execution_count=12} ``` {.julia .cell-code} dat2[1,:] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ```{=html}
DataFrameRow (3 columns)
Rowspeciessizerate
AnyAnyAny
1D.magna2.24.2
``` ::: ::: ::: {#6eae4045 .cell execution_count=13} ``` {.julia .cell-code} dat2[:,3] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ``` 2-element Vector{Any}: 4.2 3.1 ``` ::: ::: ## The CSV As with *R*, there are functions to read and write `.csv` files to and from dataframes. This makes interoperability with tools in R and standard data storage file formats easy. To write our daphnia data to a csv file, we use a familiar syntax, but a function from the `CSV` package. ::: {#76763297 .cell execution_count=14} ``` {.julia .cell-code} CSV.write("daphniadata.csv", dat2) ``` ::: Of course, you can read files in using.... yes, `CSV.read`. Note the second argument declares the data to go into a data frame. ::: {#8b4290c4 .cell execution_count=15} ``` {.julia .cell-code} daph_in = CSV.read("betterDaphniaData.csv", DataFrame) ``` :::
